title: League of Legends is losing its battle

embed.description: There's no question Blizzard's new first person shooter is a massive hit. The company already revealed that 7 million players played during the first week after launch. But there are signs that number may be underestimating how popular the game really is.

body: League of Legends is losing its battle against newcomers such as Overwatch. In Koreas Pc Bang Ranking, LoL has dropped to bellow 30% shares, which is the lowest since Feb 2013. Overwatch has closed the gap to 6% and its looking to take the first spot. Many are stopping to play League of Legends, due to massive changes to a gameplay, to coming of dynamic q and autofill. Is this the beginning of the end?

replies.body:
1: "Korean PC bangs are not representative of the world population." Korea (namely South Korea) has a relatively tiny population, but I believe some of the highest per-capita of PC gamers compared to everywhere else. It's still not indicative of the grand scheme of things.

2: Just because League is no longer the first (which they still are) doesn't mean it's a death sentence.

3: Much like the enemy getting first blood or a new champion coming out and being declared overpowered immediately, you, like so many other people on the forums, aren't waiting for the dust to settle. People flocked to Overwatch because it's new at the moment and just like League EVERYONE LIKES TO TRY THE NEW SHIT. Even after the bleed back occurs and people decide which they like more (which by the way, you CAN play more than one game), that's still not the death sentence of League people want.

4: This just means League's overwhelming popularity streak has fallen below 30% (in just South Korea, mind you!), much like someone finally killing that fucking 20/0 Zed.

5: I'm starting to think that the League community is secretly a suicide cult at this point, given how eager and giddy everyone gets talking about League's inevitable death and hoping it'll happen next week, along with the general soul-crushing defeatism that lurks in the average mind.

God knows I play much more than one game; my Steam account alone has over 100 games on it. Granted I don't play them all equally; some are not worth playing more than once, and yeah, sometimes I just want to shoot something in the face (bafflingly, I don't have a military shooter like Call of Duty.
